project.name: The Mappedin Web SDK
project.description: An easy way to render beautiful 2D or 3D maps on your website, powered by Mappedin

Mappedin.name: Mappedin
Mappedin.description:
The base Mappedin module, that has references to all the other Mappedin objects you need.

Start with Mappedin.initalize, which will get the data for a Venue from the Mappedin API, and set up a MapView, Search, and Analytics object for you.

Analytics.name: Analytics
Analytics.description:
A class to access the Mappedin Analyitcs platform. Correct usage will improve Smart Search results, and lead to more accurate insights.
This will be created for you as part of Mappedin.initialize, but you can also create one manually. You are mostly going to use `locationSelected`.

params.name: options
params.description: A list of configuration options for the Analytics API.

CameraControls.name: CameraControls
CameraControls.description:
The advanced, manual camera controls for MapView. You probably don't need to use this at all, instead relying on the MapView's focusOn*, resetCamera and built in touch/mouse controls.
This class will let you do things like change the min/max zoom, tilt, and pan, attach to camera events, and move/animate the camera to specifc points.

The camera works by setting an anchor point on the scene at ground level and pointing the camera at it. Zoom controls how far the camera is from the anchor, and tilt/rotate controls the angle the camera is rotated about it.
The camera will always be pointed directly at the anchor point. Pan or setPosition will move that anchor around on the 2D ground plane.

Created for you automatically with a MapView, don't re-create yourself.

MapView.name: MapView
MapView.description: The base MapView. This will either be 2D or 3D. Make sure you run one of Mappedin.test3D, .forceTest, .force2D or .force3D before you try an instantiate one.

params.name: container
params.description: The div to place the MapView in

params.name: venue
params.description: The results from the Mappedin API that powers this MapView

params.name: options
params.description: Some options the MapView can use.

props.name: antialias
props.description: Controls whether antialiasing is on. Defaults to true, as long as devicePixelRatio is 1. This is very expensive on high resolution screens.

props.name: onDataLoaded
props.description: A callback executed with the 3D files have been downloaded for the first map, and are starting to load into memory. The mapview is fully functional at this point, but some things will still be popping in.

props.name: onFirstMapLoaded
props.description: A callback executed when the first map is fully loaded. This means onDataLoaded has already been fired (if specified) and then all the textures and other resources have finished popping in.

props.name: firstMap
props.description: If you don't want to load the default map first, set the map you want to load first here. Useful for deep linking to a certain floor/locaiton. Since you won't have the Map object/ID until you get the Mappedin Venue data, there is a callback you can set on Mappedin.initalize to fill this in.

MapView2D.name: MapView2D
MapView2D.description: The MapView class, but in 2D. A number of these functions don't actually do anything in 2D at the moment.

params.name: container
params.description: The div to place the MapView in

params.name: venue
params.description: The results from the Mappedin API that powers this MapView

params.name: options
params.description: Some options the MapView can use.

props.name: onDataLoaded
props.description: A callback executed with the 3D files have been downloaded for the first map, and are starting to load into memory. The mapview is fully functional at this point, but some things will still be popping in.

props.name: onFirstMapLoaded
props.description: A callback executed when the first map is fully loaded. This means onDataLoaded has already been fired (if specified) and then all the textures and other resources have finished popping in.

props.name: firstMap
props.description: If you don't want to load the default map first, set the map you want to load first here. Useful for deep linking to a certain floor/locaiton. Since you won't have the Map object/ID until you get the Mappedin Venue data, there is a callback you can set on Mappedin.initalize to fill this in.

MapView3D.name: MapView3D
MapView3D.description: A 3D version MapView. Requires WebGL to run, and supports full camera pan/tilt/rotation.

params.name: container
params.description: The div to place the MapView in

params.name: venue
params.description: The results from the Mappedin API that powers this MapView

params.name: options
params.description: Some options the MapView can use.

props.name: alpha
props.description: True if the `opacity` argument to `setBackgroundColor` should be considered.

props.name: antialias
props.description: Controls whether antialiasing is on. Defaults to true, as long as devicePixelRatio is 1. This is very expensive on high resolution screens.

props.name: onDataLoaded
props.description: A callback executed with the 3D files have been downloaded for the first map, and are starting to load into memory. The mapview is fully functional at this point, but some things will still be popping in.

props.name: onFirstMapLoaded
props.description: A callback executed when the first map is fully loaded. This means onDataLoaded has already been fired (if specified) and then all the textures and other resources have finished popping in.

props.name: disableHover
props.description: If you would like to completely disable the hover effect (if you are on a touch screen for example), set this to true.

props.name: firstMap
props.description: If you don't want to load the default map first, set the map you want to load first here. Useful for deep linking to a certain floor/locaiton. Since you won't have the Map object/ID until you get the Mappedin Venue data, there is a callback you can set on Mappedin.initalize to fill this in.

Search.name: Search
Search.description: A class to access the Mappedin Smart Search API. This will be created for you as part of Mappedin.initialize, but you can also create one manually.

params.name: options
params.description: A list of configuration options for the search API.

props.name: venue
props.description: The venue slug to search for

props.name: key
props.description: Your search key

props.name: secret
props.description: Your search secret

Easing.name: Easing
Easing.description:
The easing curves you can use for any animation (path drawing, camera movement, etc.)
See [tween.js](http://tweenjs.github.io/tween.js/examples/03_graphs.html) for your options.

Tween.name: Tween
Tween.description: The Tween class from [Tween.js](https://github.com/tweenjs/tween.js). Exposed so you can create your own custom tweens.

Mappedin.name: Mappedin
Mappedin.description:
Contains the functions you need to start the MapView. Typically you will just use `Mappedin.initialize`, which does all this for you, but for special cases your flow should look like this:
 1. One of Mappedin.test3D (typcial), .forceTest, .force3D, or .force2D to put the MapView into either 2D or 3D mode.
 2. Mappedin.init to download all of the data you need from the Mappedin API
 3. new Mappedin.MapView, which will create the MapView and display the default map.

Each of those functions has a callback which you should use to trigger the next step. Once you get the final callback from the MapView
constructor, you can hide any loading screen UI and do whatever you want.

Usage:
  {{#crossLinkWrapper type}}{{#crossLink type}}{{/crossLink}}{{/crossLinkWrapper}}
Loads a Wavefront .mtl file specifying materials
classitems.author: angelxuanchang

classitems.description: Parses loaded MTL file

params.name: text
params.description: - Content of MTL file

classitems.description: Create a new THREE-MTLLoader.MaterialCreator

params.name: baseUrl
params.description: - Url relative to which textures are loaded

params.name: options
params.description:
- Set of options on how to construct the materials
                 side: Which side to apply the material
                       THREE.FrontSide (default), THREE.BackSide, THREE.DoubleSide
                 wrap: What type of wrapping to apply for textures
                       THREE.RepeatWrapping (default), THREE.ClampToEdgeWrapping, THREE.MirroredRepeatWrapping
                 normalizeRGB: RGBs need to be normalized to 0-1 from 0-255
                               Default: false, assumed to be already normalized
                 ignoreZeroRGBs: Ignore values of RGBs (Ka,Kd,Ks) that are all 0's
                                 Default: false

classitems.description:
Configuration parameter: time in milliseconds after which a
pending AJAX request is considered unresponsive and is
aborted. Useful to deal with bad connectivity (e.g. on a
mobile network). A 0 value disables AJAX timeouts.

Aborted requests resolve the promise with a ETIMEOUT error
code.

Whenever a location is selected, you should fire this event. What "selected" means can vary by venue,
but a good rule of thumb is that you fire the event whenever you would show the location's details.
Typically this is when the user taps it's polygon on the map, picks it from search results or a category list.
or deep links directly into the map.
classitems.name: locationSelected

params.name: location
params.description: The location the user selected.

classitems.description: Factor that controls how fast zooming in and out happens in response to mouse wheel events
classitems.name: zoomSpeed

classitems.description: Factor to multiple mouse movement by to get tilt/rotation.
classitems.name: rotateSpeed

classitems.description: Disable or re-enable user input.
classitems.name: enabled

classitems.description: Disable or re-enable user zoom.
classitems.name: enableZoom

classitems.description: Disable or re-enable user pan.
classitems.name: enablePan

classitems.description: Disable or re-enable user tilt/rotation.
classitems.name: enableRotate

classitems.description: This is actually the minium distance the camera can get from it's anchor on the ground. May be worth changing if your map has very tall buildings to avoid the camera clipping through them.
classitems.name: minZoom

classitems.description: Maximum distance the camera can get from it's anchor on the ground. Setting this too high will result in parts of the map falling out of the camera's clipping plane and disappearing.
classitems.name: maxZoom

classitems.description:
Constrains the camera from panning to far away from the scene. It's set automatically based on the size of the map.
If you want to change anything, you probably want to change the margin property, which is the factor the min and max in
each dimension are multiplied by to give the true bounds. For example, on a truely huge venue a 1.25 margin could get you
way out into space when zoomed in.
classitems.name: panBounds

subprops.name: margin
subprops.description: The factor the multiply the size of the geometery by to give the true camera bounds

subprops.name: min
subprops.description: An x, y pair representing the bounds of one corner of the map.

subprops.name: max
subprops.description: An x, y pair representing the bounds of the other corner of the map.

classitems.description: Minium camera tilt, in radians. If it's anything other than 0, you won't be able to look at the venue from the top down perspective.
classitems.name: minTilt

classitems.description: Minium camera tilt, in radians. If you set it too high, the camera will be able to tilt down through the geometery of the scene, which will produce clipping issues.
classitems.name: maxTilt

classitems.description: If you would really prefer to pan with the right mouse button and tilt/rotate with the left, you can swap the values here to achieve that.
classitems.name: mouseButtons

subprops.name: ORBIT=THREE.MOUSE.RIGHT
subprops.description: The button to use for tilt/rotation. Defaults to `THREE.MOUSE.RIGHT`

subprops.name: ZOOM=THREE.MOUSE.MIDDLE
subprops.description: The button to use for zoom behaviour. Don't change this.

subprops.name: PAN=THREE.MOUSE.LEFT
subprops.description: The button to use for panning the camera. Defaults to `THREE.MOUSE.LEFT`

classitems.description: Camera events you can attach a listener to (with `controls.addListener(event, function)`), if you want to do certain things. They'll be fired both by touch events and by functions you can call yourself like pan() and tilt()/
classitems.name: CAMERA_EVENTS

subprops.name: CHANGE_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired whenever the camera changes

subprops.name: PAN_START_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera starts panning

subprops.name: PAN_END_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera finishes panning

subprops.name: ROTATE_START_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera starts rotating

subprops.name: ROTATE_END_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera stops rotating

subprops.name: ZOOM_START_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera starts zooming

subprops.name: ZOOM_END_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera finishes zooming

subprops.name: MULTI_START_EVENT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera starts animating or you called setMulti. It means any one or more of pan, tilt, rotate and zoom could be changing. The individual pan/tilt/rotate/zoom events will NOT be fired.

subprops.name: MULTI_END_EVNT
subprops.description: Fired when the camera stops animating, or has finished the setMulti call.

classitems.description: Pans the camera right and down from the current position
classitems.name: pan

params.name: right
params.description: The units to move right. Negative will pan left. This is in relation to the global coordinate system, not the current camera rotation.

params.name: down
params.description: The units to move down. Negative will pan up. This is in relation to the global coordinate system, not the current camera rotation.

classitems.description: Sets the camera anchor to a specifc x/y positon, in the global reference frame. 0,0 will be roughly the middle of the map, and panBounds holds the min/max points.
classitems.name: setPosition

params.name: x
params.description: The x position to move the camera to. +x will take you right, from the default camera rotation of 0.

params.name: y
params.description: The y position to move the camera to. +y will take you down (towards the viewer) in the default camera rotation of 0.

classitems.description: Sets the rotation to a specific orientation, in radians. Mostly useful to orient the map a certain way for a physical directory.
classitems.name: setRotation

params.name: radians
params.description: Absolute rotation to set the camera to, in radians. 0 in the starting point

classitems.description: Rotates the camera a set number of radians relative to the current rotation. Useful for an idle rotation animation.
classitems.name: rotate

params.name: radians
params.description: Number of radians to rotate the camera

classitems.description: Sets the tilt to a specific level, in radians. 0 is top down. Bounded by minTilt and maxTilt
classitems.name: setTilt

params.name: radians
params.description: Tilt to set the camera to, in radians

classitems.description: Tilts the camera up or down by some number of radians. Bounded by minTilt and maxTilt
classitems.name: tilt

params.name: radians
params.description: Number of radians to increase or decrease the current tilt by.

classitems.description:
Sets the camera to be a certain distance from the anchor point, along it's tilt and rotation.
Keeps it inside minZoom and maxZoom.
classitems.name: setZoom

params.name: zoom
params.description: The distance to set the camera to

classitems.description: Moves the camera towards or away from the camera by a set amount. Positive will zoom in (bringing the distance closer to 0)
classitems.name: zoom

params.name: zoom
params.description: The distance to increase or decrease the zoom

classitems.description: Returns the current camera position
classitems.name: getPosition

return.description: An {x, y} object of the current camera postion

classitems.description: Returns the current camera rotation
classitems.name: getRotation

return.description: The current rotation of the camera, in radians

classitems.description: Returns the current camera tilt
classitems.name: getTilt

return.description: The current tilt of the camera, in radians

classitems.description: Returns the current camera zoom
classitems.name: getZoom

return.description: The distance of the camera from the anchor

classitems.description: Returns true if the camera is currently moving (it's animating, the user is manipulating it)
classitems.name: isCameraMoving

return.description: True if the camera is moving, false otherwise.

classitems.description:
Animates the camera from it's current position to the state specified in target. You only
need to specify the properties you actually want to change.

You can also specify a duration, animation curve, and a callback for when it's done.
classitems.name: animateCamera

params.name: target
params.description: A list of optional parameters you can set that represent the camera state

props.name: position
props.description: An {x, y} object representing the position to move to

props.name: zoom
props.description: The zoom level to end at

props.name: tilt
props.description: The tilt to end at, in radians

props.name: rotation
props.description: The rotation to end at, in radians

props.name: doNotAutoStart
props.description: Set this to true if you want to start the tween yourself

params.name: duration
params.description: The duration to animate the camera for, in ms

params.name: curve
params.description: The animation curve to use for the animation

params.name: callback
params.description: A callback that will be executed when the animation is done

return.description: The tween being used, if you want to do anything to control it manually. Do not overide it's events.

classitems.description: Allows you to set any of the Camera's position, zoom, rotation and tilt at once, with one function.
classitems.name: setMulti

params.name: position
params.description: an {x, y} object representing the new position

params.name: zoom
params.description: The new zoom distance

params.name: rotation
params.description: The new rotation, in radians.

params.name: tilt
params.description: The new tilt, in radians.

classitems.description: Anything we need to do after we render the camera, like update anchors for the mouse/touch controls.
classitems.name: postRender

classitems.description: Should probably be "pre-render". Anything we need to do before rendering the scene.
classitems.name: update

classitems.description: Disposes of the camera and all of it's events.
classitems.name: dispose

classitems.description:
This property identifies which mode you are in, incase you have special functionailty in your app when in 2D vs 3D mode.
It will be one of MapView, MapView3D, or MapView2D
classitems.name: type

classitems.description:
Manual camera controls for Mapview. Generally you should be using the functions on MapView like focusOn*,
but if you have some cool animations in mind, you can do it with the CameraControls.
Some of the functions don't do anything in 2D.
classitems.name: controls

classitems.description:
These are the default colours used by the Mapview to control things like path and selection. You can override these here
to quickly style your app, but most of them can also be set (especially for special cases) in their respective functions.
The only value that MUST be set here is `hover`.
classitems.name: colors

subprops.name: hover
subprops.description: The color a polygon changes to on mouse over. Defaults to `0xcccccc`

subprops.name: select
subprops.description: The color used when you call setPolygonColor with no color parameter. Defaults to `0x4ca1fc`

subprops.name: text
subprops.description: The color used for TextLabels, if you don't specify it in labelAllLocations/labelPolygons. Defaults to `0x000000`

subprops.name: path
subprops.description: The color used for the path in drawPath/drawPathSegment if you don't specify it there. Defaults to `0xff834c`

subprops.name: pathPulse
subprops.description: The color of the animated path pulse if not specified in drawPath/drawPathSegment. Defaults to `0xffffff`

subprops.name: textSelect
subprops.description: The color a TextLabel is set to when you call setPolygonColor, if you don't specify it there. Defaults to `0xffffff`

classitems.description: The Venue data this MapView is using.
classitems.name: venue

classitems.description: The div MapView is using.
classitems.name: container

classitems.description: **READ ONLY** The ID of the Map currently being displayed.
classitems.name: currentMap

classitems.description: Change this factor to influence how much the camera zooms in on a focusOn call
classitems.name: focusZoomFactor

classitems.description: Change the currently displayed map to a new one.
classitems.name: setMap

params.name: map
params.description: The map ID or Map Object to change the map to.

classitems.description: adds a map
classitems.name: addMap

params.name: map
params.description: map to add

classitems.description: removes a map
classitems.name: removeMap

params.name: map
params.description: map to remove

classitems.description: Moves the camera to focus in on a specific polygon
classitems.name: focusOnPolygon

params.name: polygon
params.description: The Polygon or polygon ID to focus on. The camera will move to the centroid of polygon

params.name: changeZoom
params.description: Whether to zoom the camera in or out so it fits the polygon's bounds. Scaled by MapView.focusZoomFactor

params.name: duration
params.description: The time the camera should spend moving, in milliseconds.

params.name: curve
params.description: The animation curve to use.

classitems.description: Moves the camera to focus on an entire path and optionally it's starting and ending polygon.
classitems.name: focusOnPath

params.name: path
params.description: The nodes to fit the camera to

params.name: polygonIds
params.description: The Polygon or polygon ID to focus on. The camera will move to the centroid of polygon

params.name: changeZoom
params.description: Whether to zoom the camera in or out so it fits the polygon's bounds. Scaled by MapView.focusZoomFactor

params.name: duration
params.description: The time the camera should spend moving, in milliseconds.

params.name: curve
params.description: The animation curve to use.

classitems.description:
A flexible function that will let you focus on collections of nodes and/or polygons.
This will move the camera to the center of all items passed in, and by default
zoom the camera in or out to fit everything in view, scaled by mapView.focusZoomFactor
classitems.name: focusOn

params.name: options
params.description: You should provide at least one node or polygon, but everything else is @optional

props.name: nodes] Node[
props.description: } An array of nodes to focus in on

props.name: polygons
props.description: An array of polygons to focus on. It's the center of the bounds of all polygons, designed to fit everything into view

props.name: duration
props.description: The duration the focus animation should last for

props.name: curve
props.description: The animation curve to use for zooming in. Uses the animateCamera one by default

props.name: focusZoomFactor
props.description: You can overide the focusZoomFactor for a specific focusOn call, rather than globally, if you liek

props.name: minZoom
props.description: Sets a floor for how close you can zoom in on the scene. If it's lower than mapView.controls.minZoom, it's ignored.

params.name: option.changeZoom
params.description: {Whether to zoom the camera in or out, or just pan it

return.description: Returns the Tween for advanced usage. Can generally be ignored.

classitems.description: Returns the value you should call setZoom on to fit the polygon exactly.
classitems.name: getZoomLevelForPolygon

params.name: polygon
params.description: The Polygon or polygon ID to get the zoom level for

return.description: The zoom level that will fit the polygon

classitems.description: Returns the value you should call setZoom on to fit the current map exactly.
classitems.name: getZoomLevelForCurrentMap

return.description: The zoom level that will fit the current map

classitems.description: Resets the pan, tilt and rotation of the camera and sets the zoom to fit the current map.
classitems.name: resetCamera

classitems.description: Returns the angle that points to north, in radians, from the default orientation.
classitems.name: getNorth

return.description: The angle to north from the default orientation, in radians

classitems.description:
Takes an element on the DOM and rotates it such that the top is pointing north. It will rotate with the camera, staying locked
on north. If you would like to align it do a different direction, or a different side of the element, pass in an offset. This
is how you would do a compass rose.

This will modify your element's transform.
classitems.name: lockNorth

params.name: element
params.description: The element on the page to rotate

params.name: offset
params.description: The amount to offset the rotation by, in radians.

classitems.description: Stops the MapView from trying to rotate your element with the camera. Do this if you remove the element, or want to stop it from rotating.
classitems.name: unlockNorth

params.name: element
params.description: The node to stop rotating. It won't reset the transform, just leave it as is.

classitems.description: Given a polygon/polygon id, set it to a specific color, and set any text label associated with that polygon to another color.
classitems.name: setPolygonColor

params.name: polygon
params.description: The polygon/polygon ID to change the color of

params.name: color
params.description: The color to use

params.name: textColor
params.description: The color to use for any TextLabel

classitems.description:
Resets a polygon back to it's original color
If the user is hovering over a polygon, it will still have the hover effect.
classitems.name: clearPolygonColor

params.name: polygon
params.description: The polygon/polygon ID to reset

classitems.description:
Resets ALL polygons you have changed with setPolygonColor back to their original color.
The hover effect will still be present if the user is currently hovering over a polygon.
classitems.name: clearAllPolygonColors

classitems.description: Makes a polygon hoverable/clickable. Polygons you haven't called this on will be treated as non-interactive and not respond to any mouse events.
classitems.name: addInteractivePolygon

params.name: polygon
params.description: The Polygon/Polygon ID to make interactive.

classitems.description: Makes a polygon no longer hoverable/clickable
classitems.name: addInteractivePolygon

params.name: polygon
params.description: The previously interactive Polygon/Polygon ID to make non-interactive.

classitems.description:
This is called when an interactive polygon is clicked on.
You will almost certainly want to replace this with your own function in your client app.
Return "false" if you have consumed the event and it shouldn't bubble down to other polygons beneath this one.
classitems.name: onPolygonClicked

params.name: polygon
params.description: The Polygon or Polygon ID that was clicked/tapped on.

return.description: False if the event has been consumed and should not bubble down to other polygons beneath it.

classitems.description:
This is fired when the user taps/clicks on the mapview without hitting an interactive polygon.
You will almost certainly want to replace this with your own function in your client app.
You would probably use this to clear any polygon highlighting, in certain situations.
classitems.name: onNothingClicked

classitems.description:
This creates a div with whatever HTML you provide, anchors it to `position` in 3D space, and optionally applies a css class you provide.
`position` should be something you got from getPositionPolygon or getPositionNode
The marker is added for you, on to the current map (or the one you specify)
classitems.name: createMarker

params.name: html
params.description: The HTML that the marker will be. Typically just some text or an image, but you can be more creative if you want.

params.name: positing
params.description: The position in 3D space to anchor the marker to. Do not attempt to create it manually: use getPositionPolygon or getPositionNode.

params.name: className
params.description: The name of the CSS class to apply to the marker

params.name: map
params.description: The map to add the marker on. Defaults to the current map.

return.description: The marker you created, which has already been added to the scene

classitems.description: Adds an already created Mappedin.Marker to the scene. The Marker constructor is more powerful than the createMarker convenience function.
classitems.name: addMarker

params.name: marker
params.description: The Marker to add

classitems.description: Removes a maker you have added previously.
classitems.name: removeMarker

params.name: marker
params.description: A Marker that has previously been returned from createMarker

classitems.description: Removes all markers (from all maps, not just the current one)
classitems.name: removeAllMarkers

classitems.description:
Takes an x/y pair in Mappedin coordinate space and gives you an object suitable to use as a Marker's position.
**Be careful about using this:** The coordinate system could change arbitrarily and without notice. You are better off
using a specific node or polygon as an anchor. If you need to use this for some reason, talk to your Mappedin representative.
classitems.name: convertTo3DMapPosition

params.name: coordinate
params.description: } A coordinate in Mappedin 2D space

return.description: The position to anchor a marker in 3D space

classitems.description: Gives you the top center of a polygon in 3d scene space. Suitable for use as a Marker's position.
classitems.name: getPositionPolygon

params.name: polygon
params.description: Either the Polygon or Polygon ID you want the center of

return.description: The position to anchor a marker in 3D space

classitems.description: Gives you the position of a Mappedin node in the 3D scene. Suitable for use as a Marker's position.
classitems.name: getPositionNode

params.name: node
params.description: Either the Node or Node ID you want the center of

return.description: The position to anchor a marker in 3D space

classitems.description:
Labels a specific polygon (or area of 3D space) with a text label that lives in 3D space. That means it will be smaller when the camera is further away, and the angle you see it at will change with the camera.
The text will flip 180 degress when the camera rotates so it's never totally upside-down.

It also sets the hover label (in 2D and 3D).
Many of these options do nothing in 2D, as TextLabels are not supported, but it won't break anything.

You must provide text, and either a Polygon, or a canvasBounds and height
classitems.name: labelPolygon

params.name: options
params.description: Most options are optional, but you do need text and either a Polygon, or a canvasBounds and height

props.name: text
props.description: The text to use for the label

props.name: polygon
props.description: The Polygon or Polygon Id to make a label for. Only optional if you have set canvasBounds and height

props.name: canvasBounds
props.description: Set this if you want to label an arbitrary part of the map. You will need to specify height as well.

props.name: x
props.description: The x coordinate for the text label anchor

props.name: y
props.description: The y coordinate for the text label anchor

props.name: width
props.description: The horizontal space we have to fit the text label

props.name: height
props.description: The vertical space we have to fit the text label

props.name: align
props.description: Whether the Text Label should be anchored against the (x,y), or the oposite (horizinal) side of the box, or in the middle. It is always vertically centered.

props.name: height
props.description: By default this is the upper bounds of the Polygon. If you don't have a Polygon, or want a custom height for some reason, you can set this.

props.name: map
props.description: If Polygon is not set, this will let you add a textLabel to another map. Otherwise, it will use the current map.

props.name: margin
props.description: The amount of space to leave before starting the text

props.name: color
props.description: A optional special color if you don't want to use mapView.colors.text

props.name: fontSize
props.description: How big to make the font. Defaults to 12

props.name: font
props.description: A THREE.Font object, if you have your own font you want to use. Create it with createFont.

props.name: scaleMin
props.description: The minimum percentange we can shrink the label to if it won't fit within the bounds at 100%. If it doesn't fit at that level, it won't be created.

props.name: scaleStep
props.description:
How much to decrement the scale each time it doesn't fit, so we don't end up with too many different font sizes on screen at once. If you are only labeling a few polygons rather than everything,
		you can set this and and scaleMin to 0.1 to fit everything except really long names perfectly.

return.description: The TextLabel, added to the scene for the correct map.

classitems.description:
Labels all locations, in order of distance from the center of the map. See labelPolygon for available label options.
The options are all optional, as the text and polygon properties will be set for each location.
classitems.name: labelAllLocations

params.name: options
params.description: Any option from labelPolygon (except text, polygon, canvasBounds, height and map), plus:

props.name: excludeTypes
props.description: is often used.
props.optdefault: []]  A list of Location types to skip labeling. ["Amenities"

props.name: sortFunction
props.description: A sorting function that will determine which Location wins when a Polygon belongs to more than one. Uses the Location.sortOrder property by default, but if you have special logic you can use it here.

props.name: locations
props.description: An array of Location objects, or location IDs. If excludeTypes and the sort function are not sufficient, you can explicitly set the locations you are labeling. You can also call labelPolygon manually for every polygon you care about instead.

classitems.description: Removes all labels from all maps
classitems.name: removeAllLabels

classitems.description: Let any image attached to a polygon attached to a location flip 180 degrees with the camera so it's always upright.
classitems.name: enableImageFlippingForAllLocations

props.name: excludeTypes
props.description: A list of Location types to skip, if for some reason there are locations that have logos that shouldn't flip

props.name: locations
props.description: An array of Location objects, or location IDs. If excludeTypes is not sufficient you can explicitly set the locations you are marking to flip. You can also call enableImageFlippingForPolygon manually for every polygon you care about instead.

classitems.description: Mark a specific polygon so, if it has an image, it rotates with the camera
classitems.name: enableImageFlippingForPolygon

props.name: polygonId
props.description: The ID of the polygon who's image (if any) should rotate

props.name: rotation
props.description: The how much the image has been rotated so that it's "up". Determined from the Polygon object itself typically, but can be set manually if needed.

classitems.description:
Create a font for use in 3D by passing in a JSON object generated from https://gero3.github.io/facetype.js/
Ignored in 2D, retuning null
classitems.name: createFont

params.name: facetypeJson
params.description: Convert a font into JSON with Facetype.js, and put it in here.

return.description: Returns the ThreeJS Font object created with the JSON, or null in 2D

classitems.description: Calculates the length of the connected path in list of Mappedin Nodes. Breaks in the path (to go to other floors) count as 0 distance. The Z value is also ignored.
classitems.name: getPathLength

params.name: path
params.description: An array of nodes on a path, probably from a Node's directionsTo or directionsFrom call.

return.description: The 2D length of the path

classitems.description:
Draws an entire path. It takes a list of nodes and will break them into separate path segments on every man change, putting the resultant segment on the right map.

If you have a special use case (like off graph nodes, or venues with same map vortexes) use the drawPathSegment function.

Returns an array of path segments if you want to customize the animation triggers. The path segements are added to the scene, chained together, and start animating automatically.
classitems.name: drawPath

params.name: path
params.description: An array of Nodes, probably from a Node's directionsTo or directionsFrom call.

params.name: options
params.description: A list of style options for the path. Not everything is supported in 2D. See drawPath for available options. Note that drawDuration is per segment.

return.description: An array of path segments.

classitems.description:
Takes a list of {x, y} pairs in Mappedin coordinate space and draws a connected path on the specified map. Use this function for special cases not handled by the drawPath convenience function.
Returns a path segment. You will need to call it's tween.start() function to begin animation and make the path segment visible.
You can customize the Tween.js tween if you like, but make sure tryRendering is always called in onUpdate or the path may stop.
classitems.name: drawPath

params.name: path
params.description: An array of Nodes, probably from a Node's directionsTo or directionsFrom call.

params.name: options
params.description: A list of style options for the path. Not everything is supported in 2D.

props.name: color
props.description: Color of path. Uses colors.path if not specified.

props.name: pulseColor
props.description: Color of path pulse. Uses colors.pathPulse if not specified. Ignored in 2D.

props.name: radius
props.description: The radius of the path

props.name: drawDuration
props.description: Duration the path fade in animation for this segment, in milliseconds.

props.name: curve
props.description: The animation curve to use for the path fade in animation.

return.description: A path segment object, with a tween property you should start(), and a reset() function to set it back to it's default state

classitems.description: Removes a specific path segement from the map it's on.
classitems.name: removePathSegment

params.name: pathSegment
params.description: A segment returned from drawPathSegment or drawPath

classitems.description: Removes all path segments from all maps
classitems.name: removeAllPaths

classitems.description: Sets the clear color of the map something else, it you want it to fit it more with your website. Otherwise the div will be white where there is no map visible.
classitems.name: setBackgroundColor

params.name: color
params.description: The color to use. Not an HTML color name.

params.name: alpha
params.description: Opacity between 0 and 1.

classitems.description:
The scene only renders when something has changed. This should be something a 3rd party developer doesn't need to worry about,
but if you are doing something weird, or have your own special tween for something, you will want to call this function.
You can call it as often as you want, it just sets a flag that we need to render again, and renders a few frames if we weren't already doing that.
Ignored in 2D.
classitems.name: tryRendering

classitems.description: Resets the MapView to the default state.

Simple utility function to calculate the maximum scroll bounds for our map so Leaflet
does not scroll outside the map bounds

Takes Mappedin Polygon data creates the corrisponding Leaflet polygon in the
map's frame of reference. Each Mappedin polygon should only have one Leaflet
polygon. Use highlightPolygon to change the styles.

Labels a specific polygon (or area of 3D space) with a text label that lives in 3D space.
That means it will be smaller when the camera is further away, and the angle you see it at will change with the camera.
The text will flip 180 degress when the camera rotates so it's never totally upside-down.

Possible options = {
	polygon - The polygon to make a label for
	canvasBounds - Optional, to do this without a real Mappedin Polygon
	height - If you don't have a real polygon, you will need to set a height
	text - The text to make the label
	margin - The amount of space to leave before starting the text
	color - A optional special color if you don't want to use mapView.colors.text
	fontSize - How big to make the font. Defaults to 12
	font - A THREE.Font object, if you have your own font you want to use.
	scaleMin - What percentage we can shrink the label to if it won't fit at 100%
	scaleStep - How much to decrement the scale each time it doesn't fit, so we don't end up with too many different font sizes
}

You must provide AT LEAST text and either polygon or canvasBounds + height.

Load the map, if it's not already loaded. Returns the old promise if it's already done, so you can safely call it whenever needed.

If needed, this could be modified to

Returns a Promise that will be Done when the OBJ, MTL and textures have been downloaded, and the objectsDictionary has been generated.

True if the canvas should be measured every frame. This is ideal to handle the user resizing the browser window on occasion, but
may not be optimal if you are trying to resize the MapView dynamically all the time.
classitems.name: shouldMeasureCanvas

classitems.description: The types of assets available for this venue.
classitems.name: ASSET_TYPES

classitems.description:
Makes a call to the Mappedin Smart Search API with the provided query, retuning a Promise that will fulfill with a
SearchResults object. This will contain a list of `hits`, which can currently be SearchItems (either SearchLocations or SearchEvents).

These are currently different from the objects you get directly from the Mappedin API,
containing a subset of their data, but you can match on their IDs.

The data is broken down into pages. You can specify the size (defaults to 10).
classitems.name: search

params.name: query
params.description: The string to search for

params.name: options
params.description: Any optional parameters you need to pass to the search API

props.name: ps
props.description: Number of search results to return. Defaults to 10. You can get the next page from SearchResults.next

props.name: type
props.description: If you want to limit your results to a specific type of SearcItem, specify it here. Currently either ASSET_TYPES.LOCATION or ASSET_TYPES.EVENT

return.description:
The promise will resolve with either a SearchResults object if successful, or an error with a `message` and `status` if it fails

		SearchResults has the following propertyies and methods:
			query: The search query that triggered this search
			total: The total number of results.
			hits: The array of SearchItems in the current page.

			A SearchItem is an object that contains an id property that could match the id of a Location or Event on your Venue object. This is NOT GUARANTEED, however, as the data could have changed since the getVenue call was performed.

			nextPage() -> A promise that will resolve with the next page of SearchResults

classitems.description:
Makes a call to the Mappedin Smart Search Suggestions API with the provided query, retuning a Promise that will fulfill with a
Suggestions object. This will contain a list of `hits`, which are words that match full search results. This should be used
to aid in autocoplete for a search bar. It's ordered for you by most relevant.
classitems.name: suggest

params.name: query
params.description: The string to get autocomplete suggestions for

return.description:
The promise will resolve with either a Suggestions object if successful, or an error with a `message` and `status` if it fails

		Suggestions has the following propertyies and methods:
			query: The suggestion query that triggered this list of suggestions (to make sure it's still what's in the text bar)
			total: The total number of suggestions.
			hits: The array of Strings matching the query

classitems.description:
The possible modes Mapview can be in. Typically you will use TEST, which will run a 3D compatibility test the user loads the page and then load load either the 2D or 3D version of MapView. On subsequent loads, it will use the saved result to avoid running a new test.
FORCE_TEST will make sure a new test is run and the results are saved, whereas 3D and 2D will force the MapView directly into 2D or 3D mode without checking for compatibility. 2D should always work but some browsers/devices do not have the WebGL support needed for 3D, so be careful.
classitems.name: modes

classitems.description:
Forces Mapview into 2D mode.
This could make a network call, so the callback will fire when that's complete and you can create a MapView.
classitems.name: force2D

params.name: callback
params.description: The function to call when the Mapview is finished loading.

classitems.description:
Forces Mapview into 3D mode.
This could make a network call, so the callback will fire when that's complete and you can create a MapView.
classitems.name: force3D

params.name: callback
params.description: The function to call when 3D mode is ready.

classitems.description:
Forces the Mapview to perform it's 3D test. It attempts to save the result the test is not run again on subsequent loads. This lets you override that behaviour.
The callback will be executed when the test is complete and either the 2D or 3D Mapview is loaded.
classitems.name: forceTest

params.name: container
params.description: The div to run the test in. Works best if it's the same as where the MapView will go, as the number of pixels being rendered is a factor.

params.name: callback
params.description: The function to call when the test is complete and either 2D or 3D mode is ready. The callback will be fired with a `result` key, a boolean that will be true if you are in 3D mode, and the result of the benchmark.

classitems.description:
This is the typical function to call before instatiating a MapView. It will either perform a test to determine if the current device is capable of running in 3D mode,
and store the results, or if prior results are available, just use those. Then, it will set Mappedin.MapView to be the constructor for the proper mode. This lets
the developer write their website without having to know or care whether the user is experiencing it in 2D or 3D. The callback you pass into the function will give you
the results, however, if you care, and you can also determine it from the `type` property on the MapView you create.

If you would like to force the test to run again, use the forceTest method instead. Or, if you want to force the user into a specific mode, use force2D or force3D respectively.
Note while 2D should work for basically anyone, if the user's device/browser does not support WebGL and you call force3D, you will get an exception when you create a MapView object.
classitems.name: test3D

params.name: container
params.description: The div to run the test in. Works best if it's the same as where the MapView will go, as the number of pixels being rendered is a factor.

params.name: callback
params.description: The function to call when the test is complete and either 2D or 3D mode is ready. The callback will be fired with a `result` key, a boolean that will be true if you are in 3D mode, and the result of the benchmark.

classitems.name: getVenue

params.name: options
params.description: Any options you need to specify to talk to the Mappedin API

params.name: clientId
params.description: The client key/ID provided to you by Mappedin to access our API. Contact your Mappedin representative if you do not have one

params.name: clientSecret
params.description: The secret/password that goes along with your ID

params.name: perspective
params.description: The name of the perspective you are using for 2D and 3D. Probably "Website". This controls what 3D files or 2D tiles get downloaded, and different persepctives may have different map features enabled/disabled, or have different images.

params.name: perspective2D
params.description: Use if you have a different perspective to use in 2D mode

params.name: perspective3D
params.description: Use if you have a different perspective to use in 3D mode

params.name: venue
params.description: The "slug" that identifies the specific Venue you are interested in. Mappedin can tell you what it is. Developer accounts often start with "api-demo1"

params.name: things
params.description: The things object is where you specifiy what fields you want to download for each object in the Mappedin API. Only specify what you will actually use, to minmimze transfer time. This SDK will ensure it has the 2D or 3D files it needs, and `id` is always included, but it won't download anything extra (like the names of locations) unless you specify it here.

props.name: venue
props.description: The Venue information you want. 'slug' and 'name' are typical, but you may also want others. Speak to Mappedin to see what is available.

props.name: locations
props.description: The fields you will be using for any Locations. You probably want at least 'name' and 'type'. You will also probably want 'description' and 'logo', but there can be any number of Location properties and it depends on your Venue and usecase. Talk to Mappedin for more details.

props.name: categories
props.description: The fields you will use for each Category. Typically 'name' at a minimum, but other common fields are 'description', 'picture', 'sortOrder' or 'parents' (for hierarchical categories) as well.

props.name: maps
props.description: The fields on each Map you are interested in. You'll probably want one or both of 'name' or 'shortName', and 'elevation' to sort.

props.name: polygons
props.description: The Polygon fields you want. The default is probably sufficient.

props.name: nodes
props.description: The Node fields you want. The default is probably sufficient.

params.name: callback
params.description: This function is called when the Venue data is loaded, or there is a problem.

props.name: error
props.description: If there is an error, you will get it here. Typically this will only be useful for developers when building/testing. It's not usually something a user can deal with.

props.name: result
props.description: A Mappedin data object with all the data you asked for. It will have a venue property with a Venue object, and locations, categories, nodes, maps, and polygons arrays

classitems.description:
This function will take a single options object combining all options for Mappedin.init and the MapView constructor, and the div the MapView should live in.
It returns a Promise that will resolve with the MapView once the 3D test has been performed, the right MapView was loaded, the data has been retrieved from the Mappedin API, and
the MapView has been created. It could also fail (mostly if the options you set for the Mappedin API are incorrect).

This is a convenience function that lets you avoid chaining a bunch of callbacks, calling test3D/force2D/force3D then Mappedin.init then the MapView constructor.
classitems.name: initialize

params.name: options
params.description: Takes an object combining all options from Mappedin.init, the MapView constructor, and the Search constructor. If you explictly want to set the 3D mode rather than run the test, it also accepts a `mode` property that can be any of Mappedin.mode

props.name: venue
props.description: Any options from Mappedin.getVenue

props.name: mapview
props.description: Any options from the Mappedin.MapView constructor

props.name: search
props.description: Any options from the Mappedin.Seach constructor.

props.name: firstMapSelector
props.description: If you would like to pick the first map loaded, set this function. It gives you a Venue object, and expects a Mappedin Map or Map Id to be returned. Return venue.defaultMap for the default behaviour. If you return an invalid map, an error will be logged to the console and an arbitrary map will be loaded.

params.name: container
params.description: The HTML element the Mapview will live in.

classitems.description:
Offline fallback service worker

This service worker is designed for offline fallback mode. If you have a network connection at all, it will get the most recent data and use that. If the network is unavailable, it will use the last downloaded version.
It has special logic to handle the paging behaviour from the Mappedin API, as a workaround for a weird bug with XHR and Service Workers where "unsafe" headers are available in fetch but not XHR.

NOTE: Using this with the Mappedin Web SDK will ensure all the resources the SDK needs are available (since it downloads everything up front), but if you want icons/logos/images from Location objects you will need to ensure your app also
tries to download them up front as well. If you do, they will be automatically cached.

NOTE2: This will cache all network traffic (which could give you offline support for free for other parts of your app) If you want to limit it to only traffic for the SDK you will have structure your app so the Mappedin
code lives in it's own folder, and you register the service worker to only handle requests from things in that folder. Read about Service Workers for more details.

Aborted requests resolve the promise with a ETIMEOUT error
code.

Missing item type
Labels a specific polygon (or area of 3D space) with a text label that lives in 3D space.
That means it will be smaller when the camera is further away, and the angle you see it at will change with the camera.
The text will flip 180 degress when the camera rotates so it's never totally upside-down.

Possible options = {
	polygon - The polygon to make a label for
	canvasBounds - Optional, to do this without a real Mappedin Polygon
	height - If you don't have a real polygon, you will need to set a height
	text - The text to make the label
	margin - The amount of space to leave before starting the text
	color - A optional special color if you don't want to use mapView.colors.text
	fontSize - How big to make the font. Defaults to 12
	font - A THREE.Font object, if you have your own font you want to use.
	scaleMin - What percentage we can shrink the label to if it won't fit at 100%
	scaleStep - How much to decrement the scale each time it doesn't fit, so we don't end up with too many different font sizes
}

You must provide AT LEAST text and either polygon or canvasBounds + height.

Load the map, if it's not already loaded. Returns the old promise if it's already done, so you can safely call it whenever needed.

If needed, this could be modified to

Returns a Promise that will be Done when the OBJ, MTL and textures have been downloaded, and the objectsDictionary has been generated.

Missing item type
Offline fallback service worker

This service worker is designed for offline fallback mode. If you have a network connection at all, it will get the most recent data and use that. If the network is unavailable, it will use the last downloaded version.
It has special logic to handle the paging behaviour from the Mappedin API, as a workaround for a weird bug with XHR and Service Workers where "unsafe" headers are available in fetch but not XHR.

NOTE: Using this with the Mappedin Web SDK will ensure all the resources the SDK needs are available (since it downloads everything up front), but if you want icons/logos/images from Location objects you will need to ensure your app also
tries to download them up front as well. If you do, they will be automatically cached.

NOTE2: This will cache all network traffic (which could give you offline support for free for other parts of your app) If you want to limit it to only traffic for the SDK you will have structure your app so the Mappedin
code lives in it's own folder, and you register the service worker to only handle requests from things in that folder. Read about Service Workers for more details.
